I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

1. 
to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the District Capitals Water Supply Project.1 
 
The project will support the Government of Timor-Leste’s efforts to meet the Millennium 
2. 
Development Goals (MDGs), particularly improved health of children under 5. The outputs of the 
project  are  (i)  rehabilitation  and  expansion  of  water  supply  systems  in  Manatuto  and  Pante 
Macasar  by  the  National  Directorate  for Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  (NDWSS),  (ii)  increased 
knowledge of efficient use of water and safe hygiene practices in project areas, (iii) sustainable 
operation and maintenance (O&M) of urban water systems by the district department for water 
supply and sanitation (DDWSS), (iv) sustainable secured water resources in Lehumo Lake, and 
(v) efficient management of the project by the Ministry of Infrastructure (MOI) and NDWSS.2  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Unsafe  water  and  inadequate  hygiene  are  two  of  the  main  causes  of  poor  health  in 
Timor-Leste and the primary causes of diarrhea. ―The two most significant causes of infant and 
child  mortality  in  Timor-Leste—lower  respiratory  infection  and  diarrheal  disease—are  directly 
related to lack of water supply and poor sanitation and hygiene.‖3 The under-5 mortality rates in 
Manatuto and Oecusse districts are higher than the national average; this is attributed in part to 
the low percentage of their populations with access to safe drinking water.4 In Pante Macasar, 
the district capital of Oecusse, and in Manatuto, the dilapidated state of water supply assets and 
the  lack  of  institutional  capacity  within  DDWSS  have  resulted  in  unsafe  and  unreliable  water 
supply  systems.5 In  Pante  Macasar,  51%  of  households  access  water  for  only  a  few  hours 
several  times  per  week  in  both  the  wet  and  dry  seasons.  In  Manatuto,  73%  of  households 
access water for only a few hours several times per week during the wet season; however, in 
the  dry  season,  59%  report  no  access  to  water  from  the  DDWSS  system.  With  37%  of  the 
population  of  Pante  Macasar  and  42%  of  Manatuto  never  having  accessed  water  from  the 
DDWSS  system,  the  gap  in  service  provision  is  considerable.6 The  water  provided  by  these 
systems  is  not  safe  for  human  consumption  due  to  lack  of  continuous  service,  low  system 
pressure, and poor maintenance of treatment and chlorination facilities. Residents of Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar currently boil and store water obtained from the system or shallow wells, but 
their storage methods lead to contamination and result in negative health impacts. 
 
4. 
Poor  hygiene  is  exacerbating  the  negative  health  impacts  caused  by  lack  of  access  to 
safe and reliable water supply. Eighty-eight percent of households in Pante Macasar and 98% in

 2 

Manatuto treat water; boiling is the most common method. While 94% had soap or detergent in 
the  house,  actual  hand-washing  practice  was  not  as  high.  Only  30%  in  both  districts  reported 
washing  their  hands  before  eating  (footnote  6).  In  Oecusse,  up  to  36%  of  the  population 
practiced open defecation; in Manatuto, a town with higher population density, this was as low 
as  11%.  Consequently,  the  incidence  of  water-related  disease  is  higher  than  the  national 
average  in  both  district  capitals.7 In  addition  to  the  direct  health  impact  on  residents,  lack  of 
access  to  safe  water  contributes  significantly  to  the  workload  of  women  because  of  the  time 
spent  managing  the  household  water  supply  as  well  as  caring  for  children  affected  by  water-
related  diseases  (a  burden  generally  assumed  by  women). 8 By  increasing  access  to  water 
supply and safe hygiene practices, the project will improve the health of residents in  Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar, particularly children, and will lessen the workload of women. 
 
5. 
The government requested urgent assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to  rehabilitate  Lehumo  Lake  to  restore  water  resources  in  Ermera  District.  The  existing  lake 
embankments  are  in  poor  condition,  do  not  retain  the  water,  and have  been  eroded. This  has 
lowered the lake’s water level, devastating the small-scale fishing relied upon by the community, 
and  putting  its  wetland  ecosystem  in  danger.9 The  rehabilitation  of    Lehumo  Lake  will  restore 
water levels, and stop erosion along the banks of the lake, which has led to a significant loss of 
land that is vital to farming activities. These water resource management measures will improve 
a  key  livelihood  source  for  farming  and  fishing-reliant  communities,  which  are  among  the 
poorest in the country.  
 
6. 
Timor-Leste’s  Strategic  Development  Plan  2011–2030  targets  the  achievement  of  six 
goals by 2030, including (i) elimination of child mortality as a consequence of inadequate water 
supply,  malnutrition,  and  lack  of  health  care;  and  (ii)  eradication  of  extreme  poverty  through 
―universal access to public services, ample job opportunities, and economic development in all 
regions.‖10 These  goals  are  directly  dependent  on  access  to  water  supply  and  sanitation  and 
improved  water  resources  management,  and  are  closely  linked  with  the  achievement  of  the 
MDGs. 11  ADB’s  2011–2015  country  partnership  strategy  for  Timor-Leste  focuses  on  the 
provision of infrastructure, including urban water supply and sanitation.12 ADB, together with the 
Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), has been investing in urban water supply since 
2002. This project will continue ADB support to the urban water supply sector by  rehabilitating 
and  upgrading  two  urban  water  supply  systems,  ensuring  their  sustainable  management,  and 
facilitating  the  development  of  public–private  partnerships  (PPPs)  for  service  provision,  in  line 
with  the  Timor-Leste  PPP  policy  and  the  draft  law  developed  with  ADB  technical  assistance 
(TA) support.13  

7. 
Since  2000,  ADB  has  provided  three  project  grants  amounting  to  $11  million  and  two 
TAs  amounting  to  $1.2 million  to  develop  the  water  and  sanitation  sector  in  Timor-Leste.  The

3 

main  development  partners  in  the  sector  are  the  Australian  Agency  for  International 
Development,  JICA,  and  the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development. 14  Most 
support from these agencies is focused on rural areas. In Oecusse and Manatuto regions, the 
United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  with  its  District Water  and  Sanitation  and 
Hygiene Program and Oxfam International have ongoing water supply and sanitation projects in 
rural communities, but the towns of  Manatuto and Pante Macasar are considered urban areas 
and cannot receive assistance under these initiatives. This is the case for all district capitals in 
Timor-Leste, which are classified as urban irrespective of their size and population density. This 
project  will  build  on  previous  urban  water  supply  projects  undertaken  by  ADB  and  JICA  while 
coordinating with rural water supply projects funded by other agencies as needed. 
 
Lessons  from  previous  projects  and  evaluation15 in  Timor-Leste  highlight  the  need  to  
8. 
(i)  provide  greater  technical  and  managerial  support  to  agencies  involved  in  water  supply,  
(ii)  increase  the  O&M  capacity  of  water  operators,  (iii)  support  sector  reforms  to  reintroduce 
tariffs  and  an  efficient  management  structure  for  NDWSS,  and  (iv)  ensure  appropriate 
institutional  capacity  is  in  place  prior  to  increasing  private  sector  involvement  in  water  supply. 
This  project  incorporates  these  lessons  by  providing  institutional  support  to  NDWSS  in 
investment  and  asset  management  planning,  and  piloting  a  phased  PPP  approach  to 
rehabilitation  and  O&M.  In  addition,  due  to  the  current  status  of  Timor-Leste  as  fragile  and 
conflict-affected,  the  project  includes  elements  of  the  2007  ADB  approach  to  engaging  with 
weakly  performing  countries,  such  as  a  strong  focus  on  extensive  community  involvement 
through  consultations,  strong  support  to  all  levels  of  government  agencies,  and  frequent 
monitoring to accommodate implementation adjustments as deemed necessary.16  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

9. 
The project will ensure that more people have access to an improved supply of drinking 
water  in  Timor-Leste;  this  will  contribute  to  reducing  the  high  incidence  of  water-related 
diseases, particularly for children under 5. By the end of the project,  NDWSS will provide safe 
and reliable water supply to the district capitals of Manatuto and Pante Macasar (outcome), and 
will  lessen  the  workload  of  women.  In  addition,  the  Ermera  community  will  properly  manage 
their water resources. The project comprises a first step in the government’s plan to provide 24-
hour access to safe drinking water in all district capitals.  
 
C. 

Outputs 

Output  1.  NDWSS  rehabilitates  and  expands  Manatuto  and  Pante  Macasar  water 
10. 
supply  systems,  including  (i)  rehabilitation  and  improvement  of  the  existing  intakes  of  both 
systems  to  maximize  gravity-fed  sources;  (ii)  in  Pante  Macasar,  development  of  a  new 
groundwater  source  to  be  used  during  the  dry  season;  (iii)  rehabilitation  and  improvement  of 
existing  storage  and  treatment  facilities;  (iv)  rehabilitation  of  existing  distribution  systems  and 
construction of new water distribution systems in four aldeias of Pante Macasar and four sucos

11. 
Output  2.  Households  in  Manatuto  and  Pante  Macasar  have  increased  knowledge  of 
efficient  use  of  water  resources  and  safe  hygiene  practices.  The  project  will  implement  an 
intensive 6-month  campaign  for  individuals  and households, followed  by  a  6-month  reinforcing 
campaign at multiple levels. The project will adapt the methodology developed in Manatuto and 
Oecusse  under  the  rural  water  program  to  the  urban  context.  The  training  will  cover  
(i)  hand  washing; (ii)  proper  handling  and  storage  of  drinking  water;  (iii) efficient  use  of  water, 
including  understanding  of  payment  for  water  and  metering;  (iv)  safe  disposal  of  wastewater; 
and (v) use of latrines by all household members, including children.  

12. 
Output  3.  DDWSS  utilizes  sustainable  O&M  of  water  systems  in  district  capitals.  The 
project will pilot a PPP approach by packaging the rehabilitation of the systems with their O&M 
for 2 years, preparing bid documents and model contracts that focus on performance standards, 
preparing  a  manual  for  system  O&M,  and  providing  DDWSS  personnel  with  on-the-job  and 
external  training  to  operate  and  maintain  the  system  and  to  monitor  contract  implementation. 
During this period, the government, in line with its PPP policy and with support from the project 
team  and ADB,  will  explore  a  long-term  PPP  arrangement for the O&M  of  urban  water  supply 
systems.  In  addition,  local  residents  will  be  sponsored  to  receive  vocational  training  on  urban 
water supply and sanitation. 

13. 
Output 4. Water resources in Lehumo Lake will be secured in a sustainable manner. To 
restore  water  resources  in  the  lake,  the  project  preparatory  TA  piloted  labor-intensive, 
community-led works to rehabilitate the lake, with more than 30% of the workers being women. 
The project will continue this approach and will (i) stop erosion through the use of gabions and 
the planting of trees, (ii) secure reasonable impermeability of the two embankments through  a 
borehole-grouting  technique,  (iii)  raise  the  embankments  and  secure  them  with  concrete,  and 
(iv) rehabilitate the broken spillway in the western embankment. 

Investment and Financing Plans 

14. 
Output  5.  MOI  and  the  implementing  agencies  provide  efficient  project  management 
and  monitoring  services.  The  project  will  provide  support  to  MOI;  NDWSS;  the  National 
Directorate  for  Roads,  Bridges,  and  Flood  Control  (NDRBFC);  and  the  communities  to 
supervise  project  implementation  and  PPP  contract  monitoring.  The  project  will  provide 
consulting  services  to  assist  NDWSS  in  preparing  a  preliminary  investment  plan  for  the 
rehabilitation and expansion  of  urban  water  supply  systems for the remaining  district  capitals. 
The government and ADB can use this plan to make decisions regarding additional financing.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

17.  MOI  will  be  the  executing  agency.  NDWSS  will  be  the  implementing  agency  for 
components related to water supply and hygiene (outputs one, two, three, and five). NDRBFC 
will be the implementing agency for the restoration of Lehumo Lake in Ermera District (output 4). 
A national steering committee, comprising MOI, NDWSS, NDRBFC, the district administrators of 
Manatuto and Oecusse, the secretary of state for the Autonomous Region of Oecusse, and the 
Directorate  for  Aid  Effectiveness  (MOF),  will  guide  project 
implementation.  A  project 
implementation  unit  (PIU)  will  be  established  to  lead  implementation  of  the  outputs  related  to 
water supply and hygiene and the ongoing Dili Urban Water Supply Sector Project.19 The chief 
of  District  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  of  NDWSS  and  the  chief  of  Dili  Water  Supply  and 
Sanitation  of  NDWSS  will  lead  the  PIU,  and  the  district  manager  of  DDWSS  of  Manatuto  and 
district manager of DDWSS of Oecusse will be members. Should the government adopt a new 
PPP  law  in 2011,  a PPP  unit  will  be  formed  to assist  the  PIU  in monitoring  implementation  of 
project contracts. The project management unit, already established for ADB road projects, will 
support  NDRBFC  in  tendering,  contracting,  and  monitoring  for  the  Lehumo  Lake  component. 
The  implementation  arrangements  are  summarized  in  Table  3  and  described  in  detail  in  the 
project administration manual (PAM).20

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

19. 
The rehabilitated water supply systems in Manatuto and Pante Macasar are expected to 
provide  efficient  and  reliable  water  service  to  their  beneficiaries  over  a  20-year  period.  High 
hardness  and  biological  contamination  in  the  river  sources  for  both  Manatuto  and  Pante 
Macasar mean treatment is necessary before distribution and is included in the project. In Pante 
Macasar, the total water demand for the next 20 years is 2,701 cubic meters per day, which can 
be met through a combination of groundwater sources (production wells) in the dry season and 
surface water sources in the rainy season. In Manatuto, the demand for water will be 26.61 liters 
per  second  by  2031  for  which  the  Laclo  River  has  sufficient  supply.  In  both  district  capitals, 
gravity-fed water supply systems are the preferred option when possible, as they are easier and 
cheaper to maintain over time than pumped systems. 
 
20. 
In  Ermera,  community-led,  small-scale  civil  works  were  piloted  during  the  project 
preparatory  TA  to rehabilitate  the  lake  and  stop  the  erosion gully  from  increasing  in  size.  The 
community  demonstrated  sufficient technical  and management  skills to undertake  some  of the

B. 

Economic and Financial 

Economic analysis indicates demand for the project as the need for water by Manatuto 
21. 
and Pante Macasar residents in 2031 cannot be met by the current water supply systems. The 
estimated  mean  willingness  to  pay  for  usage  is  $2.29  per  month  in  Manatuto  and  $1.71  per 
month  in  Oecusse.  Usage  tariffs  are  affordable  when  they  do  not  exceed  5%  of  monthly 
household incomes with 13–14 cubic meters per month consumed. The monthly water cost to 
households,  including  for  low-income  families,  remains  below  the  affordability  limit  of  5%  of 
household  income  at  current  tariffs.  Benefits  will  arise  from  the  project  through  economic  and 
health  benefits:  cost  of  illness  (24%  of  total  annual  benefits),  savings  in  income  loss  (58%  of 
total  annual  benefits),  time  savings  (15%  of  total  annual  benefits),  and  treatment  cost  savings 
(3%  of total  annual  benefits).  Further  benefits that  could not  be readily  quantified  include land 
value  appreciation  in  the  area  and  environmental  improvement.  The  project  has  an  economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) of 17%, which is higher than the assumed 12% discount rate. This 
is  notwithstanding  the  fact  that  other  benefits  relating  to  the  environment  could  not  be 
realistically  quantified  and,  therefore,  have  not  been  accounted  for  in  the  EIRRs.  The  EIRR 
remains above 12% for the following sensitivity tests: increase in capital cost by 10%, increase 
in operating cost by 10%, decrease in benefits by 10%, and a 2-year delay in implementation. 
 
22. 
Financial  analysis  of  project  components  was  undertaken  to  determine  the  capacity  of 
the  NDWSS  to  cover  project  costs.21 The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  was  calculated  for 
revenue-generating components, namely the two water supply components and is 1.9% for the 
Manatuto water  supply  component  and  1.8% for Pante Macasar. These figures are above the 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  0.59%.  The  two  components  are  sensitive  to  revenue 
decreases  and  cost  increases.  Efforts  must  be  made  during  project  implementation  to  avoid 
such  cost  increases  and  the government  must  ensure tariff reintroduction  to  all  customers. To 
help  the  district  capitals  achieve  these  targets,  the  project’s  civil  works  contractor  will  provide 
O&M for 2 years and develop appropriate maintenance plans to ensure sustainability.

D. 

Poverty and Social 

26. 
The  rehabilitated  water  supply  systems  will  have  the  capacity  to  provide  clean  and 
potable  water  to  about  30,500  people,  including  about  5,200  household  connections.  Safe, 
reliable,  and  affordable water  is  a  basic  need; fulfilling  this  need  will  directly  reduce  poverty  in 
the two district capitals. Increasing access to safe water reduces poverty by (i) improving public 
health and reducing malnutrition, resulting in reduced expenditure on health and reduced work 
days  lost  from  morbidity;  and  (ii)  increasing  time  savings  from  water  collection,  storage,  and 
boiling,  particularly  for  women  and  girls.  The  project  will  provide  (i)  access  to  metered 
household  water  connections,  (ii)  24-hour  per  day  water  service,  and  (iii)  awareness  of  safe 
hygiene  practices  to  households  in  two  district  capitals  of  Manatuto  and  Pante  Macasar.  In 
Ermera,  the  project  will  reduce  erosion  in  Lehumo  Lake,  restoring  the  lake  to  its  previous 
condition. This will reinstate small-scale fishing relied upon by the surrounding communities and 
will  open  up  the  potential  for  ecotourism  to  develop—two  livelihood  opportunities  for  reducing 
poverty in Ermera. 
 
Participation is a key element of the project’s approach to poverty reduction. The project 
27. 
will provide opportunities to form new and empower existing community-based organizations. A 
coordinating  committee  will  be  established  in  each  district  capital  to  bring  together  suco  and 
aldeia chiefs, civil society representatives, water and sanitation office officials, and project team 
to  guide  the  project,  and  to  ensure  residents’  viewpoints  are  considered  during  project 
implementation  and  that  they  are  involved  in  project  monitoring.  At  least  30%  of  members  of 
each coordinating committee will be women. Project investments will be available to all district 
capital households as the existing tariff scheme allows poor households to pay their connection 
fee over 1 year. In Ermera, a coordinating committee will also be established to guide activities 
surrounding the lake and a local  nongovernment organization will be engaged to mobilize and 
train community labor to undertake small-scale civil works. 
 
The project is categorized as gender equity theme. In Manatuto and Pante Macasar, the 
28. 
project will maximize benefits for women22 by (i) involving them in decision making through the 
coordinating  committees,  (ii)  encouraging  contractors 
labor-intensive 
construction  jobs,  and  (iii)  targeting  women  in  project  hygiene  awareness  campaigns  and 
vocational training. Women do the vast majority of water collection, storage, and treatment—the 
need for which will be reduced once households are connected to a safe, 24-hour per day water 
supply. In addition, women are the main caregivers of children, who are most affected by water-
related diseases. The physical and emotional burden of caring for sick children will be eased in 
project  areas.  In  Ermera,  the  project  will  (i)  involve  women  in  decision  making  through 
coordinating  committees,  and  (ii)  provide  cash  employment  to  women  through  community-led 
civil  works  during  project  implementation.  The  project  includes  measures  to  include  gender 
quotas  in  labor-intensive  contracts,  ensure  equal  pay  for  men  and  women,  and  avoid 
construction camps. A gender action plan was prepared and will be implemented for the project.
